item.title: Google Chrome Code Will Power The Next Microsoft Edge Browser - Forbes
item.description:
Google Chrome Code Will Power The Next Microsoft Edge Browser  Forbes

Once upon a time, Internet Explorer ruled the World Wide Web. As time went on, IE languished and was knocked off its perch by Firefox and Google Chrome. Then Microsoft fought back with a new browser called Edge. Image: Microsoft Edge was new inside and out, built to provide the best browsing experience on Windows 10. That was three years ago. Today, despite the fact that it’s an excellent browser, Edge is still struggling to draw much of a crowd. Clearly Microsoft decided that it was time for a dramatic shift in strategy. The company has announced that it’s going to completely overhaul Edge...

item.title: Microsoft may reboot its Windows web browser again - Fast Company
item.description:
Microsoft may reboot its Windows web browser again  Fast Company

When Microsoft launched Windows 10 in 2015, it came with a new web browser called Edge, which replaced the aging Internet Explorer as the default and offered interesting new features such as Cortana suggestions and page annotation. Now, sources tell Windows Central that Microsoft plans to throw out that browser and build a new one based on Chromium, an open-source engine that was originally used in Google Chrome. The new browser is reportedly codenamed “Anaheim,” and Microsoft could introduce it next year. While Edge has some interesting ideas, and it generally feels slicker and more respon...

item.title: Google Gives Developers Until Jan 1st To Fix Chrome Extension Security Issues - Forbes
item.description:
Google Gives Developers Until Jan 1st To Fix Chrome Extension Security Issues  Forbes

The latest version of the Google Chrome Web browser requires extension developers to take security more seriously than ever. (AP Photo/Paul Sakuma, file) As of August 2018, the Google Chrome web browser commanded 67.66% of the desktop browser global market share. To put that into some context, Mozilla Firefox was in second place with just 10.96% while Internet Explorer (6.97%), Safari (5.13%) and Microsoft Edge (4.24%) brought up the rear. The latest version, Chrome 70, will roll-out this month and all eyes have been on Google to see if it will do more to address the extension insecurity is...

item.title: Chinese start-up apologises over Chrome similarities - Financial Times
item.description:
Chinese start-up apologises over Chrome similarities  Financial Times

Redcore, a Chinese start-up that had boasted of its home-grown browser technology, has issued an official apology letter on its social media account on Friday after users uncovered similarities with Google’s software. In the company’s recent fundraising, there had been degrees of exaggeration that had misled the public, the company said in a letter issued Friday on its Wechat account. “We have indeed done things wrong, for which we hereby present our formal apology,” said Redcore. The home-grown browser development company said it had launched “the world’s only purely China-owned browser Re...

item.title: Google turns on default adblocker within Chrome - The Guardian
item.description:
Google turns on default adblocker within Chrome  The Guardian

Google will start automatically blocking intrusive ads within its Chrome browser for desktop and Android from Thursday 15 February. The change, announced in June, will see the dominant browser that is used by over 56% of internet users block some of the most intrusive ads including full-page prestitial ads, flashing animated ads and auto-playing video ads with sound. “A big source of frustration is annoying ads: video ads that play at full blast or giant pop-ups where you can’t seem to find the exit icon,” said Rahul Roy-Chowdhury, vice president for Chrome. “These ads are designed to be di...

item.title: The Best Chromebook - Forbes Now
item.description:
The Best Chromebook  Forbes Now

So what exactly is a Chromebook? Shortly put, it’s a laptop (or desktop) computer that runs on the Chrome OS operating system. Chromebooks primarily host data in the cloud and integrate Android web apps that make browser-based surfing, checking e-mail, updating social media, and creating documents in Google’s app suite a breeze. While you may already have a primary laptop, a Chromebook is great for use as a secondary device for busy work that’s easily accessible, and for work that can be done on the go. If you’re more inclined to use your computer for photo or video editing, if you prefer a...
